sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: With the &app; application you can watch TV, take Screenshots and record video and audio. You can browse Teletext. Closed Caption and Teletext subtitles are supported.

listitem.para: When your TV card supports video overlay the appearance can be improved by enabling the XFree86 V4L driver. Open the file /etc/X11/XF86Config and add Load "v4l" to the module section:

sect2.title: When You Start &app;
sect2.para: When you start &app;, the following window is displayed.

textobject.phrase: Shows &app; main window. Contains titlebar, menubar, toolbar, display area, and scrollbars. Menubar contains File, View, Settings, and Help menus.

sect2.para: The &app; window contains the following elements:

listitem.para: The menus on the menubar contain all of the commands you need to work with files in &app;.
The toolbar contains a subset of the commands that you can access from the menubar.
The statusbar displays information about current &app; activity and contextual information about the menu items.

sect1.title: Usage
sect1.para: You can use the &app; application to perform the following tasks:

sect2.title: To Open an Image
sect2.para:
To open an image, choose
File Open Image . The Open Image dialog is displayed. Select the file that you want to open, then click OK. To open another image in a new window, choose
File Create New Window . Choose
File Open Image
to select the file that you want to open. You can also drag an image from another application such as a file manager to the &app; window. If the &app; window is empty, the application displays the image in the window. If the window is not empty, the application starts a new window to display the file. The application displays the name of the image file and the size of the image in pixels in the titlebar of the window.
If you try to open an image file format that &app; does not recognize, the application displays an error message.

sect2.title: To Manipulate the View of an Image
sect2.para: You can use the following methods to resize the view of an image in the &app; window:

listitem.para:
To enlarge the view of an image, choose
View Zoom In .

To shrink the view of an image, choose
View Zoom Out .

To view the image at its actual size, choose
View Zoom 1:1 .

To enlarge or shrink the view of an image so that the image fits the &app; window, choose
View Fit to Window .

To enlarge or shrink the image to a specific zoom factor, choose
View Zoom factor , then choose the appropriate zoom factor from the drop-down list.

To display the image in full screen mode, choose
View Full Screen . Full screen mode displays the image in a window that fills the full screen. The window does not contain a window frame, titlebar, menubar, or toolbar. To exit from this mode, press the Esc key or
Ctrl W .

sect2.title: To Scroll an Image
sect2.para: To scroll around an image that is larger than the image window or full screen window, you can use the following methods:

listitem.para: Use the arrow keys on the keyboard.
Drag the image in the opposite direction to the direction in which you want to scroll. For example, if you want to scroll down the image, drag the image upwards in the window.
Use the scrollbars on the window.

sect2.title: To Close an Image
sect2.para:
To close an image, choose
File Close This Window . If the window is the last &app; window open, the application exits.

To quit &app; and close all of the windows that you opened in the current session, choose
File Exit .

sect1.title: Settings
sect1.para:
To configure &app;, choose
Settings Preferences . The Preferences dialog contains the following tabbed sections:

sect3.title: Video Device
sect3.para: In this section you can select the device file name of the kernel device to be used in capture mode. Common names are:
Changes will take place after you quit and restart &app;.

sect3.title: Audio Device
sect3.para: Here you can select an audio device to record sound. Usually a kernel device is the best choice because &app; has better control over what is recorded. If your TV card has audio sampling hardware and the driver supports this, you can also select the TV card as recording device. This will free the soundcard to record from other sources.
Common kernel device names are /dev/dsp, /dev/dsp0, /dev/dsp1 and so on. Click on the down arrow of the device file entry to see a list of devices found by &app;.

If the audio output of your TV card connects to the audio input of your soundcard, or when your TV card has no audio capabilities you will want to select Control volume with soundcard mixer. This has two advantages:

listitem.para: &app; will properly set the volume control on the soundcard mixer and the TV card, you do not have to start a mixer application.
When you change the volume or mute audio, recording is not affected.

sect3.para: If you selected a soundcard as audio recording device, you must enable this option to select an audio input line.
Common mixer device names are /dev/mixer, /dev/mixer0, /dev/mixer1 and so on. Click on the down arrow of the device file entry to see a list of devices found by &app;.

sect3.title: Main Window
sect3.para: You can set the following preferences:

listitem.para: &app; does not support session management yet. When this option is selected, it will save the window geometry on exit and restore on startup in a non-standard way.
In video mode (not Teletext mode) disable the screensaver from blanking the screen.
When this option is selected &app; will save and restore brightness, contrast, audio volume and other settings when you switch channels.

When you enter channel numbers on the numeric keypad or with your remote control, &app; can interpret the numbers differently. In the United States you will want to choose by RF channel number (1 to 125). You can also choose by the number of the channel in the channel list, the first channel has number 0.
Name of the current channel, e.g. BBC1
Number in the channel list
RF channel name, e.g. S02
Tuning frequency
Video standard (PAL, NTSC, SECAM, …)
Current video input on the TV card

sect3.title: Video Options
sect3.para: You can set the following preferences:

listitem.para: When switching to fullscreen display mode, &app; cannot enlarge the video to cover the whole screen, but it can change the display resolution to approximately the size of the video. Here you can select a particular resolution, automatic selection, or no change of display resolution.
With the XVideo extension the image scaling hardware of your graphics card can be used to display captured video at nearly any size. You can select the size of the captured video:
Fixed size 320 x 240 pixels
The largest size supported by the video capture hardware, or the window size if smaller
Interlaced video looks funny when scaled. This mode is similar to Interlaced, except noninterlaced video will be captured.

Here you can customize the Appearance submenu of the main window context menu. To add new line, click on the Add button. To remove a line, click on the line and then the Remove button. To change values, click on a line and then the desired column.
When you select this option, the video window can only assume sizes which are a multiple of 32 pixels.

sect3.title: Keyboard
sect3.para: In this section you can customize accelerators. Note that built-in accelerators such as those associated with menus or channel number entering on the numeric keypad take precedence.

To add new accelerator, click on the Add button. To remove an accelerator click on the line and then the Remove button. To change a command, click on the line and type a new command in the command entry. Click on the down arrow to see a list of commands. To change a keyboard shortcut, click on the line and column.

sect3.title: Audio Options
sect3.para: Here you can select whether &app; should automatically mute audio when the application starts, or before it quits.

sect3.title: OSD Options
sect3.para: Some operations such as entering a channel number or changing the audio volume by keyboard can display a status message. Here you can customize this On Screen Display.

listitem.para: Whether to display messages superimposed onto the video (OSD), in a status bar of the video window, in a separate console window, or not at all.
How long the message will visible in OSD mode.
Font to be used in OSD mode.
Foreground (text) color to be used in OSD mode.
Background color to be used in OSD mode.

When this option is selected, &app; will capture and decode VBI data transmitted by the current TV station. This enables Teletext browsing, Teletext subtitles, Closed Caption, and &app; can automatically name the station (if the information is transmitted, respectively).
A dedicated kernel device is necessary to capture VBI data. If this is supported by your TV card and its driver, you can select the VBI device here. Common names are:
The device should correspond to the selected kernel video device. &app; will try to find it automatically, but this may fail. Changes will take place after you quit and restart &app;.
If you have only an XVideo device, unfortunately you cannot use these functions because XVideo does not support VBI data capturing.

This is a Teletext option. Some stations fail to transmit a complete language identifier, so the Teletext viewer may not display the correct font or national characters. You can select your geographical region here as an additional hint.

The Teletext standard knows different implementation levels. The built-in Teletext browser supports them all. You can select if you want to see pages as displayed by simpler decoders. Note most stations still only transmit at the basic levels 1.0 or 1.5.
You can freely resize Teletext windows. There are different ways to do this, some give better results, others are faster. Select here the mode you like best.

sect3.title: Screenshot plugin
sect3.para: In this section you can customize the screenshot plugin.

listitem.para: A shell command to execute after the image has been saved. The following environment variables will be set:
The fully qualified filename of the saved image, e.g. /home/my/shots/image2.jpg
Name of the current channel, e.g. BBC1
RF channel name, e.g. S02
Video standard (PAL, NTSC, SECAM, …)
Current video input on the TV card
By default a screenshot is taken when you open the screenshot dialog. When this option is selected, it will be taken when you click the OK button of the dialog.
Add a button to the main window toolbar which opens the screenshot dialog.
Use this drop-down list box to specify the interpolation method that &app; uses when the application resizes images. Select one of the following options:

This method of interpolation takes a location in the original image and replicates the pixel that is nearest to this location. When you zoom in on an image, the pixels are replicated. When you zoom out of an image, the image loses some of its detail.

This is a simple and fast method of interpolation. When you zoom in on an image, &app; uses up to four adjacent pixels to compute the colors of the new pixels. When you zoom out of an image, &app; averages regions of color in the existing image to compute the colors of the pixels.
This is a high-quality, slow method of interpolation. The application performs interpolation on the image in the manner described in Digital Image Warping by George Wolberg.
Default: Nearest neighbor.
Use this drop-down list box to specify how &app; displays transparent or partially opaque backgrounds in images. Select one of the following options:
This option displays black and dark gray checks.
This option displays dark gray and light gray checks.
This option displays light gray and white checks.
This option displays solid black.
This option displays solid gray.
This option displays solid white.
Default: Dark checks.

Use this drop-down list box to specify the size of the checks to use to display transparent or partially opaque backgrounds in images. This option is only relevant if you choose Dark checks, Midtone checks, or Light checks from the Transparency type drop-down list box. Select one of the following options:
Default: Small.

Use this drop-down list box to specify the dithering method to use to display images. Dithering is a technique that is used to simulate colors in the original image file but that your system can not display. Select one of the following options:
This option does not use dithering.
This option performs dithering on pseudocolor displays, which use a limited palette of colors.
This option performs dithering on pseudocolor and high color displays.
Default: None.

Select this option to render an image in two passes when you scroll the image quickly. The first pass renders a low quality version of the image. The second pass renders a full quality version of the image over the low quality version. Two-pass scrolling enables you to view at least a low quality version of the image at all times regardless of how quickly you scroll the image.
Default: unselected.

sect2.title: Viewers
sect2.para: You can set the following viewer preferences:

sect3.title: Image Windows
sect3.para: The Image Windows group contains the preferences that you can set to view images in image windows.

listitem.para: Use this drop-down list box to specify when to use scrollbars to scroll through an image. Select one of the following options:
This option never displays scrollbars. You can use the arrow keys on the keyboard or the mouse to scroll through the image.

para.guilabel: Only if image does not fit

listitem.para: This option displays scrollbars when the image is larger than the image window.
Default: Never.

term.guilabel: Pick window size and zoom factor automatically

listitem.para: Select this option to resize the image window to fit the image or to resize the image to fit the image window. If the image is small, &app; resizes the image window to fit the image. If the image is large, &app; resizes the image to fit the image window.
Default: unselected.

term.guilabel: Open images in a new window

listitem.para: Select this option to open a new &app; window each time you open an image. If you do not select this option, &app; replaces the existing image with the new image when you open an image.
Default: unselected.

sect3.title: Full Screen
sect3.para: The Full Screen group contains the preferences that you can set to view images in full screen mode.

listitem.para: Use this drop-down list box to specify when to use scrollbars to scroll through an image. Select one of the following options:
This option never displays scrollbars. You can use the arrow keys on the keyboard or the mouse to scroll through the image.

para.guilabel: Only if image does not fit

listitem.para: This option displays scrollbars when the image is larger than the full screen.
Default: Never.
Select this option to use the 1:1 zoom factor when you open an image. The 1:1 zoom factor displays the image at its actual size.
Default: selected.

term.guilabel: Use same zoom factor as image window

listitem.para: Select this option to use the same zoom factor that the application uses to display the image in an image window.
Default: unselected.
Select this option to resize images to fill the full screen when you open the images in full screen mode.
Default: unselected.

Select this option to automatically resize images that are the same size as standard screens so that the images fill the full screen when you open them in full screen mode. If you select this option, &app; ignores the settings for the previous three options when you open an image that is the same size as a standard screen. Examples of standard screen sizes are 640 x 480 pixels, 1024 x 768 pixels, and so on.
Default: unselected.

term.guilabel: Put a bevel around the edge of the screen

listitem.para: Select this option to display a 3D beveled border around the full screen view of an image.
Default: unselected.

sect1.title: Channel Editor
sect1.para:
To open the channel editor, choose
Edit Channels . In the channel editor you can edit the channel list. It can contain tuned channels (if your TV card has a tuner) as well as composite and S-Video inputs.
The channel editor dialog shows three sections. At the top the frequency table and related options. In the middle the channel list. At the bottom you can edit individual channel list entries.

sect2.title: Populating the Channel List
sect2.para: First you must choose the frequency table used in your country. To do this, select a country from the drop-down menu in the top left corner of the dialog. Then you can:

listitem.para: Click on Automatic station search

If this is supported by your TV card &app; will scan all RF channels in the frequency table and enter the found stations in the channel list. When VBI decoding has been enabled in the preferences it will also try to determine the station names.
Click on Add all channels
This will add all RF channels in the frequency table to the channel list.
Click on Import XawTV configuration
This will import the channel list from the XawTV configuration file, if you used the XawTV application before.
Naturally you can also enter channels one by one yourself.

sect2.para: Now you can edit channel names or reorder channels on the list. When you are satisfied click on OK to store your changes and leave the dialog.

sect2.title: Editing the Channel List
sect2.para: To select an entry in the channel list just click on the row. To select multiple rows click on the first row, then press-and-hold Shift and click on the last row.

sect3.title: Adding and Removing Channels
sect3.para: To add a new channel, click on the Add button. To insert a channel at a particular position, select the respective row first.
New channels are empty and will not show in menus. You can leave it this way to create a gap in the list. That is useful when you switch channels by entering the number in the list.
To remove one or more channels, select the rows and click on the Remove button.

sect3.title: Reordering Channels
sect3.para: Select one or more rows and click on the Up or Down button.

sect3.title: Editing Channels
sect3.para: It is not possible yet to edit the channel list directly. Instead select a row and edit in the box at the bottom of the dialog. Channels have the following properties:

listitem.para: The name you want to give the channel.

Typically TV cards have a tuner, composite and S-Video inputs. Here you can select the input to be used when you switch to this channel. When you select Do not change input a switch to this channel will not change the input.

To change the radio frequency (the RF channel) select a different row from the frequency table, in the top right corner of the dialog. If necessary you can select a different frequency table for each channel.
Here you can adjust the radio frequency. As with the radio frequency this property is only applicable if the current video input is a tuner.

Typically TV cards support more than one video standard. Here you can select the video standard to be used when you switch to this channel. When you select Do not change standard a switch to this channel will not change the video standard.
A keyboard shortcut to switch to this channel.

sect1.title: Zapzilla
sect1.para: Zapzilla is the built-in Teletext viewer of Zapping.

textobject.phrase: Zapzilla window. Contains titlebar, menubar, toolbar, display area showing a Teletext page, and statusbar. The menubar contains File, Edit, Go and Bookmarks menus.

sect2.title: Go to a Page
sect2.para: To go to a different page simply type the page number on the keyboard. You can also press the cursor keys to go to the next or previous page or subpage. Or you can click on a page number in the psge. When you click with the middle mouse button the page opens in a new window.
